title-group.article-title: Higher order theory based Fourier analysis of cross-ply plates and doubly curved panels

article-meta.aff: Centre for Marine Technology and Engineering (CENTEC), Technical University of Lisbon, Instituto Superior Técnico, Lisbon, Portugal

author-notes.corresp: C Guedes Soares, Centre for Marine Technology and Engineering (CENTEC), Technical University of Lisbon, Instituto Superior Técnico, Av. Rovisco Pais, 1049-001 Lisbon, Portugal Email: guedess@mar.ist.utl.pt

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: An analytical solution to the static analysis of a general cross-ply finite-dimensional doubly curved panel of rectangular plan-form, modeled using a higher order shear deformation theory, is presented. A solution methodology, based on boundary-discontinuous generalized double Fourier series approach is used to solve a system of five highly coupled linear partial differential equations, generated by the higher order-based laminated shell analysis, with the fully clamped type 4 (C4) boundary condition prescribed on two opposite edges, while the remaining two edges are subjected to the simply supported type 4 (SS4) constraint. The numerical accuracy of the solution is ascertained by studying the convergence characteristics of the deflection and moment of a cross-ply spherical panel, and also by comparison with the available results in literature. Additional comparisons were made with the finite element counterparts using commercially available software for distributed load. Hitherto unavailable important numerical results presented include sensitivity of the predicted response quantities of interest to shell geometry (cylindrical and spherical), lamination, lamina material property, thickness and membrane effects as well as their interactions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Advanced composite materials offer significant advantages relative to conventional materials such as high ratios of stiffness and strength-to-weight; superior resistance to environmental conditions (e.g., glass fiber composites), design flexibility also known as tailoring the material for desired application. All these advantages make them attractive for a wide range of applications in marine, chemical, aerospace, automotive industries, and for applications related to medical and sporting goods.1,2 But all these advantages of composite structures, however, bring additional difficulties such as the inter-laminar or transverse shear stress due to mismatch of material properties among layers, bending-stretching coupling due to asymmetry of lamination, and in-plane orthotropy. Extra complexities arise due to the necessity of the satisfaction of the prescribed boundary conditions.

The majority of analytical or strong form of solutions to the boundary value problems using the classical lamination theory (CLT) of thin rectangular cross-ply plates utilizing either Navier’s and Levy’s approaches are based on the well-known method of separation of variables. Such solutions represent particular solutions whenever the method of separation of variables work, and when these particular solution functions fortuitously satisfy the prescribed boundary conditions.

The present solution technique utilizes the double Fourier series approach, first discussed by Hobson,3 and used by Goldstein4,5 to solve the stability problems of fluid flow. Green6 used the double Fourier series approach for the solution to the problem of a clamped isotropic plate. Green and Hearmon7 extended this approach to solve the problems of symmetrically laminated thin isotropic plates with simply supported boundary conditions. Solution for cross-ply and angle-ply laminates with clamped boundary conditions was presented by Whitney8 utilizing this method. Whitney and Leissa9 obtained the exact solution to the static and dynamic response of antisymmetric cross-ply and angle-ply laminated plates for various boundary conditions assuming displacement functions in the form of double Fourier series. Whitney10 also utilized the same method for the solution of buckling and vibration of clamped anisotropic plates. Whitney and Pagano11 used the first order shear deformation theory (FSDT) and obtained exact solution for cross-ply laminated rectangular plates for SS3 boundary conditions assuming displacement functions in the form of double Fourier series.

A closed-form solution of a very long and narrow cross-ply laminate using FSDT for clamped edge boundary conditions was presented by Kan and Ito.12 Sivakumaran13 presented the solution of rectangular plates with completely free edges utilizing Rayleigh–Ritz approach considering a complete power series as admissible functions for displacements. Malhotra et al.14 obtained the effect of fiber orientation on free vibration of orthotropic rectangular plates for five different boundary conditions based on Rayleigh–Ritz energy approach using conventional beam functions. Barbero et al.15 presented a two-dimensional theory including geometric nonlinearity and Navier-type solutions (i.e., simply supported type 3 (SS3) boundary conditions prescribed at all edges).

Exact solutions were developed based on a generalized Levy-type approach by Khedeir16,17 to the free vibration of antisymmetric angle-ply laminated plates for various boundary conditions. Tauchert18 successfully applied the FSDT into the thermal buckling problem of thick antisymmetric angle-ply laminated plates with SS2 boundary condition. Lim and Reddy19 obtained solutions considering the CLT and higher order shear deformation theory (HSDT) for simply supported rectangular plates, rectangular plates with two opposite simply supported edges, and clamped rectangular plates.

Ferreira et al.20 presented a trigonometric shear deformation theory through the thickness direction, allowing for zero transverse shear stresses at the top and bottom surfaces of the plate for modeling symmetric composite plates discretized by a meshless method based on global multiquadric radial basis functions and provided solutions for the simply supported, clamped, and free edge conditions. Lin and Jen21 used Chybeshev collocation method for the solution of laminated anisotropic plates for different simply supported and clamped boundary conditions. A first-order plate theory based on the mixed variational theorem that satisfies prescribed lateral conditions and displacements was due to Kim and Cho22 for the analysis of thick composite plates and sandwiches. Akhras and Li23 developed a spline finite strip method based on a higher order theory. Results were presented for sinusoidal and distributed loading conditions and simply supported boundary conditions. Bhaskar and Sivaram24 presented a superposition method for isotropic/specially orthotropic plates with arbitrary transverse load and arbitrary combination of boundary conditions.

Chaudhuri and Kabir25,26 presented exact solutions using a novel discontinuous double Fourier series approach developed by Chaudhuri27,28 in solving highly coupled second-order partial differential equations. Generally the CLT and FSDT theories were considered in the solutions for thin and moderately thick laminated plates and shells for SS1, SS2, SS4, and C4 type boundary conditions for cross-ply, angle-ply, and arbitrary laminations. Only HSDT-based solution for considering SS2 boundary condition is due to Chaudhuri and Kabir.29 Levy type analytical solutions using the same solution technique were presented by Oktem and Chaudhuri30–32 to the problem of deformation of a finite-dimensional general cross-ply thick rectangular plates, modeled using HSDT. Following Levy type problems, a new HSDT based analytical solution for general cross-ply plates, and subjected to the clamped edge 3 (C3) conditions prescribed at all four edges, was solved analytically using the boundary discontinuous double Fourier series technique by Oktem and Chaudhuri.33

Recently, analytical solutions pertaining to C3 type boundary condition to the problem of the static analysis of the doubly curved shell panel, for simply supported type 1 (SS1) and simply supported type 4 (SS4) boundary conditions of plate problems, and for SS1 type boundary condition of doubly curved panels were presented by Oktem and Chaudhuri.34–36 A detailed review of the literature and the boundary discontinuous double Fourier series solutions to the general type boundary value problems is available in Oktem.37

The above literature review reveals that there is still gap for the analytical solutions to the general problem of static response of HSDT-based flat, singly and doubly curved panels, with general admissible boundary conditions prescribed at the edges. The available HSDT-based solutions for cross-ply plates or shallow curved panels are primarily limited to only Navier38 (i.e., all edges are SS3) or Levy type39,40 (i.e., two opposite edges are SS3). In the latter case, only one type of in-plane or surface-parallel boundary constraint has been considered within each category of supported boundaries, such as simply supported and clamped.

The primary objective of the present study is to provide analytical solution to the boundary value problem by considering a higher order theory using boundary discontinuous Fourier technique for symmetric (e.g., 0°/90°/0°, 0/°90°/90°/0°), and antisymmetric (0°/90°) cross-ply doubly curved panels (plates are special cases of the shells) for the simply supported type-4 boundary condition described on two opposite edges and fully clamped type-4 boundary conditions described on the remaining edges. As a second objective, numerical result are presented to understand the complex deformation behavior of the cylindrical and spherical panels of symmetric and antisymmetric cross-ply constructions for this type of boundary condition, investigate the effect of various parameters such as material properties, effect of curvature, lamination sequence, etc.

sec.title: Statement of the problem
sec.p:
The laminated doubly curved shell, composed of finite number of orthotropic layers of uniform thickness of h is shown in Figure 1. The ξ1 and ξ2 curves are lines of curvature on the shell mid-surface, ξ3 = ζ = 0, while ξ3 = ζ is a straight line normal to the mid-surface. The cross-ply shell under consideration is composed of a finite number of orthotropic layers of uniform thickness. The principal radii of normal curvature of the reference (middle) surface are denoted by R1 and R2. In order to model the static behavior of the shell, an additional set of simplifying assumptions are invoked: (i) transverse inextensibility, (ii) moderate shallowness (in regards to the normal curvatures), and (iii) negligibility of geodesic curvature. For a cylindrical shell, the lines of principal curvature coincide with the surface-parallel coordinate lines, while for a spherical shell, the same can be assumed upon negligence of the geodesic curvatures of the coordinate lines. The last two assumptions permit the use of curved panel coordinates x1, x2, x3 = ζ, attached to the panel mid-surface. Small elastic deformation is assumed (i.e., displacements and rotations are small, and obey Hooke’s law). The displacement field by considering the cubic terms and satisfying the conditions of transverse shear stresses (and hence strains) vanishing at a point (ξ1, ξ2, ± h/2) on the outer (top) and inner (bottom) surfaces of the shell, is given by as follows:38 (1a)u¯1=(1+ζR1)u1+ζφ1-c1ζ3(φ1+1g1u3,1), (1b)u¯2=(1+ζR2)u2+ζφ2-c1ζ3(φ2+1g2u3,2), (1c)u¯3=u3, where, ui(i=1,2,3) denotes the displacements of a point on the middle surface, while φ1 and φ2 are the rotations at ζ = 0 with respect to the ξ2 and ξ1 axes, respectively, and c1 = 4/(3h2). The corresponding strain–displacement relations are given by:38 (2a)ɛ1=ɛ10+ζ(κ10+ζ2κ12), (2b)ɛ2=ɛ20+ζ(κ20+ζ2κ22), (2c)ɛ4=ɛ40+ζ2κ41, (2d)ɛ5=ɛ50+ζ2κ51, (2e)ɛ6=ɛ60+ζ(κ60+ζ2κ62), in which (3a-c)ɛ10=u1,1+u3R1, κ10=φ1,1, κ12=-c1(φ1,1+u3,11), (3d-f)ɛ20=u2,2+u3R2, κ20=φ2,2, κ22=-c1(φ2,2+u3,22), (3g-h)ɛ40=u3,2+φ2, κ41=-3c1(φ2+u3,2), (3i-j)ɛ50=u3,1+φ1, κ51=-3c1(φ1+u3,1), (3k-m)ɛ60=u2,1+u1,2, κ60=φ2,1+φ1,2, κ62=-c1(φ2,1+φ1,2+2u3,12). Figure 1.
Geometry of a laminated doubly curved panel.

The governing partial differential equations obtained using the principal of virtual work and they are as follows: (4a)N1,1+N6,2=0, (4b)N6,1+N2,2=0, (4c)Q1,1+Q2,2-3c1(K1,1+K2,2)+c1(P1,11+P2,22+2P,12)-N1R1-N2R2=-q, (4d)M1,1+M6,2-Q1+3c1K1-c1(P1,1+P6,2)=0, (4e)M6,1+M2,2-Q2+3c1K2-c1(P6,1+P2,2)=0, where q is the distributed transverse load, and Ni, Mi, Pi, i = 1, 2, 6, which denote stress resultants, stress couples (moment resultants), and second stress couples (resultants of the second moment of stress), are as defined by Reddy and Liu.38 Qi, i = 4,5, represents the transverse shear stress resultants. They are written as follows: (5a)Ni=Aijɛj0+Bijκj0+Eijκj2, (5b)Mi=Bijɛj0+Dijκj0+Fijκj2, (5c)Pi=Eijɛj0+Fijκj0+Hijκj2, (i, j=1,2,6) (6a)Q1=A5jɛj0+D5jκj1, (6b)Q2=A4jɛj0+D4jκj1, (6c)K1=D5jɛj0+F5jκj1, (6d)K2=D4jɛj0+F4jκj1, (j=4,5).

In which Aij,Bij, etc. are the laminate rigidities (integrated stiffnesses). These are given as follows: (7a)(Aij,Bij,Dij)=∑k=1N∫ξk-1ξkQij(k)(1,ξ,ξ2)dξ, (7b)(Eij,Fij,Hij)=∑k=1N∫ξk-1ξkQij(k)(ξ3,ξ4,ξ6)dξ.

Introduction of Equations (5), (6), and (7) into Equations (4a–e) gives five highly coupled fourth-order governing partial differential equations. The set of equations can be expressed in the following form: (8a)Kijxj=fi (i, j=1,…,5)and(Kij=Kji), where (8b){xj}T={u1 u2 u3 φ1 φ2}, (8c){fj}T={0 0 -q 0 0}. and Kij are given in Appendix A.

In the following, the above system of five partial differential equations given by Equation (8) is solved in conjunction with the C4-SS4 type mixed simply supported and clamped boundary conditions defined as follows:

The fully clamped type (C4) boundary conditions prescribed at the edges x1=0, a: (9a)u1=u2=u3=φ1=φ2=u3,1=0, and, the simply supported type (SS4) boundary conditions prescribed at the edges x2=0, b: (9b)u1=u2=u3=φ1=M2=P2=0.

sec.title: Solution procedure
sec.p: The solution of the partial differential equations (8a) in conjunction with the admissible boundary conditions given by Equations 9(a) and (b) is assumed as follows: (10a)u1(x1,x2)=∑m=0∞∑n=1∞Umncos(αx1)sin(βx2), 0≤x1≤a;0<x2<b (10b)u2(x1,x2)=∑m=1∞∑n=0∞Vmnsin(αx1)cos(βx2), 0<x1<a;0≤x2≤b (10c)u3(x1,x2)=∑m=1∞∑n=1∞Wmnsin(αx1)sin(βx2), 0≤x1≤a;0≤x2≤b (10d)φ1(x1,x2)=∑m=0∞∑n=1∞Xmncos(αx1)sin(βx2), 0≤x1≤a;0≤x2≤b (10e)φ2(x1,x2)=∑m=1∞∑n=0∞Ymnsin(αx1)cos(βx2), 0≤x1≤a;0≤x2≤b where (11)α=mπa, β=nπb.

Introduction of assumed displacement functions into the partial differential equations given by Equation (8a) generates 5mn+2m+2n unknown (panel or interior) Fourier coefficients. The next step is comprised of partial differentiation of the assumed particular solution functions. The procedure for differentiation of these functions is based on Lebesgue integration theory that introduces boundary Fourier coefficients arising from discontinuities (complementary boundary constraints Chaudhuri27,28 of the particular solution functions at the edges x1 = 0, a. The function u1 given by Equation (10a) and its first partial derivative, u1,1 obtained by term-wise differentiation, are not satisfied at the edges, x1 = 0, a, thus violating the boundary constraints and complementary boundary constraints, respectively, at these edges. Therefore, u1 is forced to vanish at these edges (boundary constraints), while for further differentiation, u1,11 is expanded in double Fourier series, in the form suggested by Chaudhuri,27,28 in order to satisfy the complementary boundary constraint (inequality). The partial derivatives are then obtained as follows:28 (12a)u1,1=-∑m=1∞∑n=1∞αUmnsin(αx1)sin(βx2), (12b)u1,11=∑m=1∞12a¯nsin(βx2)+∑m=1∞∑n=1∞[-α2Umn+γma¯n+Ψmb¯n]cos(αx1)sin(βx2), (12c)u1,122=∑m=1∞∑n=1∞αβ2Umnsin(αx1)sin(βx2), (12d)u1,22=-12∑n=1∞β2U0nsin(βx2)-∑m=1∞∑n=1∞β2Umncos(αx1)sin(βx2).

In a manner similar to u1, u2 is forced to vanish at the edges, x2=0 and b. The derivatives of u2 are given in equations (13). (13a)u2,2=-∑m=1∞∑n=1∞βVmnsin(αx1)sin(βx2), (13b)u2,22=12∑m=1∞c¯msin(αx1) +∑m=1∞∑n=1∞[-β2Vmn+γnc¯m+Ψnd¯m]sin(αx1)cos(βx2).

Furthermore, the function φ1 given by Equation (10d) and the first partial derivative of the transverse displacement, u3,1 obtained by term-wise differentiation (see below), are two rotational quantities associated with the present HSDT, which are not satisfied at the edges, x1 = 0 and a, thus violating the boundary constraints. Therefore, these two rotational quantities are forced to vanish at these edges (boundary constraints). Their next partial derivatives, φ1,1 and u3,11, which are changes of curvature, are seen to vanish at the edges, x1 = 0 and a, thus violating the complementary boundary constraints (boundary discontinuities) at these edges. Therefore, for further differentiation, φ1,11 and u3,111 are expanded in double Fourier series in order to satisfy the complementary boundary constraint (inequality). A similar argument holds for obtaining the partial derivatives of the rotational quantities, φ2 and u3,2 obtained by term-wise differentiation (see below), which are not satisfied at the edges, x2 = 0 and b. The partial derivatives of interest can be written as follows:28 (14a)φ1,1=-∑m=1∞∑n=1∞αXmnsin(αx1)sin(βx2), (14b)φ1,11=12∑n=1∞e¯nsin(βx2)+∑m=1∞∑n=1∞[-α2Xmn+γme¯n+Ψmf¯n]cos(αx1)sin(βx2), (14c)φ1,12=-∑m=1∞∑n=1∞αβXmnsin(αx1)cos(βx2), (15a)u3,1=∑m=1∞∑n=1∞αWmncos(αx1)sin(βx2), (15b)u3,11=-∑m=1∞∑n=1∞α2Wmnsin(αx1)sin(βx2), (15c)u3,111=12∑n=1∞g¯nsin(βx2)+∑m=1∞∑n=1∞[-α3Wmn+γmg¯n+Ψmh¯n]cos(αx1)sin(βx2), (15d)u3,12=∑m=1∞∑n=1∞αβWmncos(αx1)cos(βx2).
The boundary Fourier coefficients appear in Equations (12)–(15), a¯n, b¯n, c¯m, d¯m, e¯n, f¯ng¯n, and h¯n are defined in Appendix B, and (16)(γn,Ψn)={(0,1),n=odd,(1,0),n=even.

The remaining partial derivatives can be obtained by term-wise differentiation. The above step generates additional 6n+2m unknown (boundary) Fourier coefficients. Satisfying the geometric boundary conditions in Equations (9a–b) such as u1, u2, φ1, and u3,1 vanishing at the appropriate edges, and equating the coefficients of sin(αx1), cos(βx2), etc. yield the algebraic equations (17a–d).
For all values of m=1,2,…(17d)∑n=1,3,5,…∞ΨnVmn=0, Vm0+∑n=2,4,6,….∞γnVmn=0.

On equating the coefficients of sin(αx1), sin(βx2), sin(αx1), etc. in the equilibrium and boundary equations result in totally, 5mn + 4m + 8n linear algebraic equations in as many unknown and furnish a complete solution to the boundary value problem considered here In the interest of the computational efficiency, in the first step, Equations (8) are first solved for Umn, Vmn, Wmn, Xmn, Ymn in terms of the unknown boundary Fourier coefficients a¯n, b¯n, etc. either numerically or symbolically. In this work, Umn, Vmn, Wmn, Xmn, Ymn were solved in terms of the unknown boundary Fourier coefficients symbolically by using the MAPLE symbolic language. Resulting equations are only composed of unknown boundary Fourier coefficients. In the second step, they are substituted in the geometric boundary equations given by (17a–d) and resulting linear equations are solved for boundary Fourier coefficients such as a¯n, b¯n, etc. by using the classical solution techniques such as Gaussian elimination, etc. In the final step, calculated numerical values of the boundary Fourier coefficients (a¯n, b¯n, etc.) are substituted back in the first step and Umn, Vmn, Wmn, Xmn, Ymn are calculated. This useful step will reduce the size of problems under consideration by an order or more of magnitude. Solution steps are also shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Flow chart for solution.

sec.title: Numerical results and discussions
sec.p:
Numerical results are given for symmetric ([0°/90°/0°] and [0°/90°/90°/0°]) and antisymmetric [0°/90°] cross-ply cylindrical (for either R1 → ∞ or R2 → ∞), spherical panels of square planform, and plates (special case of spherical panel, both R1 → ∞ and R2 → ∞), subjected to uniformly distributed transverse load applied to the structure. The following material properties are assumed:
Material type I: E1 = 175.78 GPa (25,000 ksi); E1/E2 = 25; G12/E2 = G13/E2 = 0.5; G23/E2 = 0.2; ν12 = 0.25
Material type II: E1 = 105.47 GPa (15,000 ksi); E1/E2 = 15; G12/E2 = G13/E2 = 0.4286; G23/E2 = 0.3429; ν12 = 0.40 in which E1 and E2 are the in-plane Young’s moduli in x1 and x2 coordinate directions, respectively, while G12 denotes in-plane shear modulus. G13 and G23 are transverse shear moduli in the x1–x3 and x2–x3 planes, respectively, while ν12 is major Poisson's ratio on the x1–x2 plane. The following normalized quantities are defined: (18a, b)u3*=103E2h3q0a4u3, M1*=103q0a2M1, (18c, d)u1*=103E2h3q0a4u1, φ1*=102E2h3q0a3φ1.

In which ‘a’ is assumed to be equal to 812.8 mm (32 in.), and q0 denotes the transverse load. For all the numerical results presented in all figures except the Figures 17–24, the displacements, u3* and the moments M1*, are computed at the center of the panel.

Figure 3 displays the convergence (with m = n) of normalized central transverse displacement (deflection), u3* and moment, M1* of a moderately thick (a/h = 10) and moderately deep (R1/a = R2/b = 10) antisymmetric cross-ply [0°/90°] spherical panel of square (a = b) planform, computed using the present HSDT with the material type I. The normalized displacement, u3* exhibits a rapid and monotonic convergence. Unlike the displacement, moment M1* shows initial oscillatory convergence for m = n < 10. Figure 3.
Convergence of normalized central deflection, u3* and moment M1* of an antisymmetric moderately thick cross-ply [0°/90°] spherical panel.

Comparisons of the present results with available ones from the literature to verify the solution are presented in Tables 1–3 for isotropic and orthotropic plates with different aspect ratios (a/b), respectively. Material type I is used for the orthotropic plate, while for isotropic plate, Poisson’s ratio υ = 0.3 is taken.41 It is important to note that the solution in Reddy41 is a Levy type solution. The results are in good agreement with the isotropic counterparts. The discrepancy between the two sets of results for the orthotropic plate can be attributed to the fact that the boundary condition used in Reddy,41 unlike the present one, does not utilize the additional boundary conditions (e.g., in-plane displacements; u1=u2 = 0) at the respected edges. Table 1.
Comparison of normalized central deflections and bending moments in isotropic (υ=0.3) rectangular plates subjected to uniformly distributed load for aspect ratios b/a ≤ 1
Variable b/a = 1/3 b/a = 1/2 b/a = 1
Reddy41 Present Reddy41 Present Reddy41 Present
w∧ 1.1681 1.1679 0.8445 0.8441 0.1917 0.1915
M∧xx 0.4214 0.4222 0.4738 0.4744 0.3326 0.3327
M∧yy 1.1442 1.1436 0.8693 0.8685 0.2445 0.2438
Table 2.
Comparison of normalized central deflections and bending moments in isotropic (υ=0.3) rectangular plates subjected to uniformly distributed load for aspect ratios b/a > 1
Variable b/a = 3/2 b/a = 2 b/a = 3
Reddy41 Present Reddy41 Present Reddy41 Present
w∧ 0.2476 0.2476 0.2612 0.2621 0.2619 0.2625
M∧xx 0.4067 0.4065 0.4214 0.4209 0.4201 0.4185
M∧yy 0.1794 0.1780 0.1441 0.1418 0.1302 0.1250
Table 3.
Comparison of normalized central deflection and bending moment in orthotropic square plates subjected to uniformly distributed load
Variable Reddy41 Present
w∧ 0.0108 0.0126
M∧xx 0.4331 0.4507

Figures 4 and 5 present comparisons of the variations of the normalized central deflections, u3* and central moment, M1* with a/h ratio of symmetric [0°/90°/0°] and antisymmetric cross-ply [0°/90°] plates for material type I and II. The normalized central deflections, u3* of the antisymmetric cross-ply plate are noticeably higher than their symmetric counterparts, though the difference progressively decreases as the aspect ratio, a/h, decreases from thin to moderately thick range, and thereafter, more sharply decreases in the thick laminate regime (5 ≤ a/h ≤ 10). This difference in behavior can be attributed to the ‘beam-column effect’ caused by the bending-stretching coupling present in the antisymmetric laminate. It is also important to note that bending-stretching coupling may either cause in-plane compression (‘beam-column effect’) or in-plane stretching (called ‘tie-bar’ effect) in a plate subjected to bending Oktem and Chaudhuri.34 The former has a softening effect while the latter has a stiffening effect on the laminated plate response. The normalized central moments, M1* for symmetric [0°/90°/0°] plates are markedly higher as compared to their antisymmetric [0°/90°] counterparts; however, the central moment, M1* in contrast to u3*, are almost same for both material types and it decreases from [0°/90°/0°] to [0°/90°] laminate in the entire range of a/h considered as given in Figure 5. Figure 4.
Variation of normalized central deflection, u3* with a/h ratio of a symmetric [0°/90°/0°] and antisymmetric [0°/90°] cross-ply plate for material type I and II. Figure 5.
Variation of normalized central moment, M1* with a/h ratio of a symmetric [0°/90°/0°] and antisymmetric [0°/90°] cross-ply plate for material type I and II.

Figure 6 presents comparisons of the variations of the normalized central deflections, u3* and central moment, M1* with a/h ratio, of moderately deep (R/a = 10) spherical panels of three different laminations. The normalized central deflections of the two symmetric cross-ply panels are almost same in the entire range of the length-to-thickness ratio, a/h considered. In contrast, the normalized central deflection, u3* of the antisymmetric cross-ply panel is higher than their symmetric counterparts. Figure 6 further shows that the normalized central moments, M1* are markedly higher for antisymmetric [0°/90°] as compared to their counterparts symmetric ([0°/90°/0°] and [0°/90°/90°/0°]) panels. Figure 6.
Variation of normalized central deflection, u3* and central moment, M1* with a/h ratio of a symmetric ([0°/90°/0°], [0°/90°/90°/0°]) and antisymmetric ([0°/90°]) cross-ply spherical panel (R/a=10) for material type I.

Variations of normalized central deflection, u3* of [0°/90°] spherical panels, with a/h and R/a ratios are presented in Figures 7 and 8, respectively. Figure 7 shows that the transverse (inter-laminar) shear deformation has a dominant effect on the response in the thicker panel regime, a/h < 20. In both plots, membrane action due to the effect of curvature is seen to progressively play an important role, particularly starting from the ratio R/a ≤40, in the thinner panel regime.32,36 This membrane action has a complex interaction with the ‘beam-column/tie-bar’ effect caused by the bending-stretching coupling present in the antisymmetric [0°/90°] panels. Furthermore, in the case of thicker panels (a/h < 10), the influence of the membrane action is supplanted by the effect of transverse (inter-laminar) shear deformation. Membrane and shear effects are also visible in Figure 9. Figure 7.
Variation of normalized central deflection, u3* with a/h ratio of an antisymmetric cross-ply [0°/90°] panel for different R/a ratios for material type I. Figure 8.
Variation of normalized central deflection, u3* with R/a ratio of an antisymmetric cross-ply [0°/90°] spherical panel for different a/h ratios. Figure 9.
Variation of normalized central deflection, u3* with R/a ratio of an antisymmetric cross-ply [0°/90°] and symmetric ([0°/90°/0°], [0°/90°/90°/0°]) spherical panel for different a/h ratios.

Figures 10 to 13 display the variations of the normalized central moment, M1* with a/h and R/a ratios for antisymmetric [0°/90°] and symmetric ([0°/90°/0°], [0°/90°/90°/0°]) spherical panels. In contrast to u3*, the membrane action has a strong effect in both the thick and the thinner panel regime particularly for R/a ≤40, as mentioned above. Figure 10.
Variation of normalized central moment, M1* with a/h ratio of an antisymmetric [0°/90°] and symmetric [0°/90°/0°] spherical panel for different R/a ratios for material type I. Figure 11.
Variation of normalized central moment, M1* with R/a ratio of an antisymmetric cross-ply [0°/90°] panel for different a/h ratios for material type I. Figure 12.
Variation of normalized central moment, M1* with R/a ratio of a symmetric [0°/90°/0°] spherical panel for different a/h ratios for material type I. Figure 13.
Variation of normalized central moment, M1* with R/a ratio of a spherical panel for different laminations for a moderately thick panel (a/h=10).

Figures 14 and 15 present the variations of normalized central deflections, u3* of moderately thick (a/h = 10) antisymmetric [0°/90°] and symmetric [0°/90°/0°] cross-ply one spherically and two cylindrically curved panels with respect to R/a ratio, respectively. The response of the [0°/90°] spherical and cylindrical panels is not the same particularly for the values of R/a < 40. It is important to note that the different behavior, in order to show the clear effect of the in-plane changes on the boundaries dictated by the fully clamped and simply supported conditions in the current problem, which has not been observed on any other boundary condition earlier.31,32,34,36 Contrary to clamped type 3 boundary condition,34 the behavior of the normalized u3* values of the [0°/90°] cylindrical panel, with R1 and R2 are altered, where R1 → ∞, is higher (softening effect) than its spherical counterpart particularly for the values of R/a < 40. In contrast, u3* of the [0°/90°] cylindrical panel, with R2 → ∞, is lower (hardening effect) than its spherical counterpart in the entire range of the R/a ratio considered. Additionally, the response of the [0°/90°] spherical panel becomes almost identical to its cylindrical counterpart (R1 → ∞) for the values of R/a ≥ 40. However, the behavior of the spherical and cylindrical panels is almost same for the entire range of the R/a ratio for the symmetric laminations as given in Figure 15. The difference in character between the antisymmetric and symmetric laminations is mainly, the well-known beam-column/tie-bar effect due to bending-stretching coupling, which is inherited in antisymmetric laminations. It has a complex interaction with the membrane action due to curvature. This is a very important factor that should be considered particularly at the initial design stages of composite shells. Figure 14.
Variation of normalized central deflection, u3* with R/a ratio for antisymmetric [0°/90°], and for a moderately thick (a/h=10) spherical and cylindrical panels (Material I). Figure 15.
Variation of normalized central deflection, u3* with R/a ratio for symmetric [0°/90°/0°], and for a moderately thick (a/h=10) spherical and cylindrical panels (Material I).

Variation of normalized central deflection, u3* of moderately deep (R/a = 10) antisymmetric [0°/90°] panel with the a/h ratio is presented in Figure 16. The normalized central deflections of the spherical and the cylindrical panels are almost same in the entire range of the a/h ratio, unlike what is already observed in the case of the all edges SS1 and SS3-SS2 boundary conditions,31,36 wherein there is a considerable difference in normalized central deflections, u3* of the spherical and the two cylindrical panels for the a/h > 10 (SS1 case), and between the cylindrical panel (R1 → ∞) with the cylindrical (R2 → ∞) and spherical counterparts for the entire range of the a/h ratio (SS3-SS2 case). Figure 16.
Variation of normalized central deflection, u3* with a/h ratio for antisymmetric [0°/90°], and for a moderately deep (R/a=10) spherical and cylindrical panels (Material I).

Variations of u1*,u2*,u3*,φ1*,M1*, and M2* of moderately deep (R/a = 10) and moderately thick (a/h = 10) antisymmetric [0°/90°] and symmetric [0°/90°/0°] spherical panels, computed at and along x1=0 to a, and x2=0 to b are shown in Figures 17–20, respectively. The normalized deflection, u3* assumes its respective maximum magnitude at the center of the panel, where the surface-parallel displacement, u1* and rotation, φ1* vanish. u1* and φ1* reach their respective maximum values at x1 = a/4 and x1 = 3a/4. On the other hand, the normalized moment, M1* reaches its maximum value at the edges x1 = 0 and x1 = a, dictated by the C4 boundary condition as given in Figures 17 and 18. The normalized deflection, u3* and the moment, M2* assume their respective maximum magnitudes at the center of the panel (x2=b/2) where displacement, u2* vanishes. u2* reaches its maximum values at x2 = b/4 and x2 = 3b/4, dictated by the SS4 boundary condition as given in Figure 19 for antisymmetric [0°/90°] laminate. The normalized deflection, u3* reaches the maximum value at the center for the symmetric [0°/90°/0°] case as presented in Figure 20; however, the moment, M2* and displacement, u2* reaches their respective maximum magnitudes at x2 = b/4 and x2 = 3b/4. Additionally, these plots clearly indicate the satisfaction of the boundary conditions, as exactly specified by the boundary discontinuous double Fourier series approach used in the present analysis. Figure 17.
Variations of displacements, rotation, and moment along the center line, x2=b/2, of a moderately thick (a/h=10) antisymmetric [0°/90°] spherical panel. Figure 18.
Variations of displacements, rotation, and moment along the center line, x2=b/2, of a moderately thick (a/h=10) symmetric [0°/90°/0°] spherical panel. Figure 19.
Variations of displacements, rotation, and moment along the center line, x1=a/2, of a moderately thick (a/h=10) [0°/90°] spherical panel. Figure 20.
Variations of displacements, rotation, and moment along the center line, x1=a/2, of a moderately thick (a/h=10) symmetric [0°/90°/0°] spherical panel.

Further comparisons of the present case with the finite element results for the antisymmetric [0°/90°] and symmetric [0°/90°/0°] thick (a/h = 5) and moderately thick (a/h = 10) plates for material type I are shown in Figures 21–24, respectively. For that purpose, a finite element model is prepared by using available commercial finite element software ANSYS. Finite element results were obtained computed at and along x1=0 to a (between the two fully clamped edge (x2=b is constant)). Results are in close agreement with the finite element counterparts. However, there are some discrepancies between the two sets of results at the fully clamped edges particularly for the antisymmetric [0°/90°] laminates due to the fact that there is a sharp change of the spatial quantities close to the edges and the difference between the HSDT and FSDT, while the present solution utilizes the former, the present finite element code use the latter theory for the calculations. It is also important to note that the differences between the two sets of results are decreased for symmetric laminates. Figure 21.
Variations of FEA and present results for displacement and moment along the center line, x2=b/2, of a thick (a/h=5) antisymmetric [0°/90°] plate. Figure 22.
Variations of FEA and present results for displacement and moment along the center line, x2=b/2, of a moderately thick (a/h=10) antisymmetric [0°/90°] plate. Figure 23.
Variations of FEA and present results for displacement and moment along the center line, x2=b/2, of a thick (a/h=5) symmetric [0°/90°/0°] plate. Figure 24.
Variations of FEA and present results for displacement and moment along the center line, x2=b/2, of a moderately thick (a/h=10) symmetric [0°/90°/0°] plate.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An analytical solution to the problem of symmetric and antisymmetric cross-ply panels with the mixed fully clamped (C4)- fully simply supported (SS4) type boundary condition prescribed at all four edges is presented. The boundary-discontinuous double Fourier series based solution methodology is employed to solve the problem characterized by a system of five highly coupled linear partial differential equations. The complementary boundary constraints are introduced through boundary discontinuities of some of the particular solution functions and their partial derivatives for the derivation of the complementary solution.

The present work is verified by comparing the results with the available ones in the literature and they are further compared with the finite element counterparts for some cases. The results show the complex effect of the interaction among the in-plane boundary conditions, transverse shear deformation, bending-stretching coupling, membrane effect and the effect of material property. They are expected to contribute to a deeper understanding of the complex deformation behavior of the cross-ply plates and shells for the different boundary conditions. The numerical results presented here should serve benchmark comparisons with numerical results such as finite element, boundary element and meshless methods. They can particularly be used for the initial conceptual design stages of composite shells of the laminated structures.

sec.p: The first author has been financed by the Portuguese Foundation of Science and Technology under the contract number SFRH/BPD/47687/2008.

sec.title: Conflict of interests
sec.p: There is no conflict of interest.

sec.title: Appendix A: Definition of constants in Equation (8)
Appendix B: Definition of boundary Fourier coefficients
sec.p: The unknown boundary Fourier coefficients are defined as follows: (B.1)a¯n=4ab∫0b[u1,1(a,x2)-u1,1(0,x2)]sin(βx2)dx2, (B.2)b¯n=4ab∫0b[u1,1(a,x2)+u1,1(0,x2)]sin(βx2)dx2, (B.3)c¯m=4ab∫0a[u2,2(x1,b)-u2,2(x1,0)]sin(αx1)dx1, (B.4)d¯m=-4ab∫0a[u2,2(x1,b)+u2,2(x1,0)]sin(αx1)dx1, (B.5)e¯n=4ab∫0b[φ1,1(a,x2)-φ1,1(0,x2)]sin(βx2)dx2, (B.6)f¯n=-4ab∫0b[φ1,1(a,x2)+φ1,1(0,x2)]sin(βx2)dx2, (B.7)g¯n=4ab∫0b[u3,11(a,x2)-u3,11(0,x2)]sin(βx2)dx2, (B.8)h¯n=-4ab∫0b[u3,11(a,x2)+u3,11(0,x2)]sin(βx2)dx2.
